title: How to Make Healthy Egg Whites for Breakfast

steps.headline: Whisk together the egg whites, water, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Separate the egg whites from the yolks and place them into a bowl; save the yolks for another recipe. Whisk in the water along with a pinch of salt and a dash of pepper. Set the bowl aside.

steps.headline: Sauté the spinach over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Heat the olive oil in a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the spinach along with some salt and pepper. Cook the spinach, stirring constantly, until the leaves wilt and become tender. Don't like spinach? No problem! Try it with thinly-sliced mushrooms instead! For a more hearty meal, try: sliced mushrooms, chopped onions, and diced green bell peppers.

steps.headline: Pour the egg whites into the skillet.
steps.description: Use a spatula to spread the spinach around so that it covers the bottom of the skillet in an even layer. Pour the egg whites on top and tilt the skillet around to help them spread.

steps.headline: Cook the omelet until the egg whites begin to set.
steps.description: Once they start to turn white, lift up the edges of the omelet with a spatula for a few seconds. This will allow any uncooked egg white to flow underneath and cook.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the cheese down the middle of the omelet.
steps.description: Start with the cottage cheese, then finish off with a sprinkle of parmesan. If you don't have these two cheeses on hand, you can try ricotta and/or Romano instead. You can also omit one of the cheeses and just use one type. Mozzarella is another tasty option.

steps.headline: Fold the omelet in half.
steps.description: Slide a spatula under the omelet partway, then quickly flip it over like closing a book. Alternatively, you can fold both of the side edges to the middle so that they overlap, like a brochure.

steps.headline: Slide the omelet onto a plate and serve it.
steps.description: Do this quickly; the egg whites will continue to cook even after you remove them from the skillet. If you want to, you can garnish the omelet further with some diced tomatoes or sun dried tomatoes.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C).
steps.description: Grease a 12-count muffin tin with butter, oil, or cooking spray, then set it aside. For smaller cups, use a 24-count mini muffin tin.

steps.headline: Pour 2½ cups (595 milliliters) of egg whites into a bowl.
steps.description: You use store-bought egg whites that come in a carton, or you can separate the egg whites yourself using fresh eggs. If you plan on using fresh eggs, however, you will need 20 to 24 eggs. For a fluffier muffin, add 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of non-fat milk or plain, Greek yogurt.

steps.headline: Stir the vegetables and herbs into the bowl.
steps.description: You can also use other vegetables or create your own unique combination. Other great choices include: bacon crumbles, ham, onions, red peppers, and sausage. If you are making these for your family, consider putting the ingredients into bowls, then letting your family members build their own muffin cups.

steps.headline: Whisk in the cheese, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: You can also try other cheeses, such as colby or pepper jack. Feta cheese goes especially well with mushrooms and spinach.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into the muffin cups.
steps.description: Fill each cup about two-thirds of the way; this will give the muffin cups space to rise. Make things easier by using a soup or sauce ladle for this step; this way you can be sure that each cup gets the same amount.

steps.headline: Bake the muffin cups for 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when the egg whites turn white and puffy. If you are making mini muffins, reduce the baking time to 15 to 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Allow the muffin cups to cool before removing them from the pan.
steps.description: Place the muffin pan on a wire cooling rack, and let the muffin cups cool for about 5 minutes. Run a knife along the inside edge of each cup, then scoop the muffin cup out with a fork.

steps.headline: Garnish the muffin cups, if desired, then serve them.
steps.description: You can serve them with diced avocado, salsa, or a sprinkle of fresh herbs, such as chives. Allow any leftover muffin cups to cool completely before freezing them; store them in plastic, re-sealable freezer bags. Re-heat frozen muffin cups in the microwave for 45 seconds.

steps.headline: Preheat the broiler on your oven.
steps.description: Move the rack until it is 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) from the heat. While the oven pre-heats, you will prepare the omelet on the stovetop.

steps.headline: Sauté the shallot and thyme in a skillet.
steps.description: Heat 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of melted butter in a medium-sized, nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add in the shallot and thyme, and cook until they turn fragrant, stirring constantly. This will only take about 30 seconds. Make sure that you are using an oven-safe skillet, such as cast-iron on. Use a potholder or oven mitt to handle the skillet.

steps.headline: Add in the mushrooms, salt, and pepper, and continue cooking.
steps.description: Toss in the sliced mushrooms, then season them with some salt and pepper. Allow the mushrooms to cook over medium-high heat until they brown slightly. This will take about 5 minutes. If you don't like mushrooms, you can try spinach instead, or even diced tomatoes! Keep in mind that the cooking times may differ.

steps.headline: Whisk together the egg whites, salt, pepper, and butter.
steps.description: While the mushrooms are cooking, separate the egg whites from the yolks, and place them into a bowl; reserve the yolks for another recipe. Add in some salt and pepper, and 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of melted butter. Whisk everything together until the whites turn frothy and doubled in volume. This will give you a fluffier omelet in the end.

steps.headline: Add the egg whites and cook them over medium-low heat.
steps.description: Use a spatula to lift the edges of the omelet up so that the uncooked egg white can flow underneath it. You are ready for the next step when the egg whites begin to set and turn light brown on the bottom; this will take about 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Place the skillet into the oven.
steps.description: Let the omelet bake until the top sets, about 10 to 30 seconds. As soon as the top sets, use a potholder or oven mitt to pull the skillet out of the oven.

steps.headline: Fold the omelet in half or into thirds.
steps.description: Slide a spatula under half of the omelet, then flip it over onto itself. Alternatively, you can fold the left and right sides to the middle so that they overlap.

steps.headline: Serve the omelet on a plate.
steps.description: Use the spatula to slide the omelet off of the skillet and onto a plate.

text: Making a Spinach Omelet Whisk together the egg whites, water, salt, and pepper. Separate the egg whites from the yolks and place them into a bowl; save the yolks for another recipe. Whisk in the water along with a pinch of salt and a dash of pepper. Set the bowl aside. Sauté the spinach over medium-high heat. Heat the olive oil in a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the spinach along with some salt and pepper. Cook the spinach, stirring constantly, until the leaves wilt and become tender. Don't like spinach? No problem! Try it with thinly-sliced mushrooms instead! For a more hearty meal, try: sliced mushrooms, chopped onions, and diced green bell peppers. Pour the egg whites into the skillet. Use a spatula to spread the spinach around so that it covers the bottom of the skillet in an even layer. Pour the egg whites on top and tilt the skillet around to help them spread. Cook the omelet until the egg whites begin to set. Once they start to turn white, lift up the edges of the omelet with a spatula for a few seconds. This will allow any uncooked egg white to flow underneath and cook. Sprinkle the cheese down the middle of the omelet. Start with the cottage cheese, then finish off with a sprinkle of parmesan. If you don't have these two cheeses on hand, you can try ricotta and/or Romano instead. You can also omit one of the cheeses and just use one type. Mozzarella is another tasty option. Fold the omelet in half. Slide a spatula under the omelet partway, then quickly flip it over like closing a book. Alternatively, you can fold both of the side edges to the middle so that they overlap, like a brochure. Slide the omelet onto a plate and serve it. Do this quickly; the egg whites will continue to cook even after you remove them from the skillet. If you want to, you can garnish the omelet further with some diced tomatoes or sun dried tomatoes. Making Hearty Muffin Cups Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C). Grease a 12-count muffin tin with butter, oil, or cooking spray, then set it aside. For smaller cups, use a 24-count mini muffin tin. Pour 2½ cups (595 milliliters) of egg whites into a bowl. You use store-bought egg whites that come in a carton, or you can separate the egg whites yourself using fresh eggs. If you plan on using fresh eggs, however, you will need 20 to 24 eggs. For a fluffier muffin, add 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of non-fat milk or plain, Greek yogurt. Stir the vegetables and herbs into the bowl. You can also use other vegetables or create your own unique combination. Other great choices include: bacon crumbles, ham, onions, red peppers, and sausage. If you are making these for your family, consider putting the ingredients into bowls, then letting your family members build their own muffin cups. Whisk in the cheese, salt, and pepper. You can also try other cheeses, such as colby or pepper jack. Feta cheese goes especially well with mushrooms and spinach. Pour the mixture into the muffin cups. Fill each cup about two-thirds of the way; this will give the muffin cups space to rise. Make things easier by using a soup or sauce ladle for this step; this way you can be sure that each cup gets the same amount. Bake the muffin cups for 20 to 25 minutes. They are ready when the egg whites turn white and puffy. If you are making mini muffins, reduce the baking time to 15 to 20 minutes. Allow the muffin cups to cool before removing them from the pan. Place the muffin pan on a wire cooling rack, and let the muffin cups cool for about 5 minutes. Run a knife along the inside edge of each cup, then scoop the muffin cup out with a fork. Garnish the muffin cups, if desired, then serve them. You can serve them with diced avocado, salsa, or a sprinkle of fresh herbs, such as chives. Allow any leftover muffin cups to cool completely before freezing them; store them in plastic, re-sealable freezer bags. Re-heat frozen muffin cups in the microwave for 45 seconds. Making a Baked Mushroom Omelet Preheat the broiler on your oven. Move the rack until it is 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) from the heat. While the oven pre-heats, you will prepare the omelet on the stovetop. Sauté the shallot and thyme in a skillet. Heat 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of melted butter in a medium-sized, nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add in the shallot and thyme, and cook until they turn fragrant, stirring constantly. This will only take about 30 seconds. Make sure that you are using an oven-safe skillet, such as cast-iron on. Use a potholder or oven mitt to handle the skillet. Add in the mushrooms, salt, and pepper, and continue cooking. Toss in the sliced mushrooms, then season them with some salt and pepper. Allow the mushrooms to cook over medium-high heat until they brown slightly. This will take about 5 minutes. If you don't like mushrooms, you can try spinach instead, or even diced tomatoes! Keep in mind that the cooking times may differ. Whisk together the egg whites, salt, pepper, and butter. While the mushrooms are cooking, separate the egg whites from the yolks, and place them into a bowl; reserve the yolks for another recipe. Add in some salt and pepper, and 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of melted butter. Whisk everything together until the whites turn frothy and doubled in volume. This will give you a fluffier omelet in the end. Add the egg whites and cook them over medium-low heat. Use a spatula to lift the edges of the omelet up so that the uncooked egg white can flow underneath it. You are ready for the next step when the egg whites begin to set and turn light brown on the bottom; this will take about 3 minutes. Place the skillet into the oven. Let the omelet bake until the top sets, about 10 to 30 seconds. As soon as the top sets, use a potholder or oven mitt to pull the skillet out of the oven. Fold the omelet in half or into thirds. Slide a spatula under half of the omelet, then flip it over onto itself. Alternatively, you can fold the left and right sides to the middle so that they overlap. Serve the omelet on a plate. Use the spatula to slide the omelet off of the skillet and onto a plate.
sentences: Making a Spinach Omelet Whisk together the egg whites, water, salt, and pepper.
Separate the egg whites from the yolks and place them into a bowl; save the yolks for another recipe.
Whisk in the water along with a pinch of salt and a dash of pepper.
Set the bowl aside.
Sauté the spinach over medium-high heat.
Heat the olive oil in a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat.
Once the oil is hot, add the spinach along with some salt and pepper.
Cook the spinach, stirring constantly, until the leaves wilt and become tender.
Don't like spinach?
No problem!
Try it with thinly-sliced mushrooms instead!
For a more hearty meal, try: sliced mushrooms, chopped onions, and diced green bell peppers.
Pour the egg whites into the skillet.
Use a spatula to spread the spinach around so that it covers the bottom of the skillet in an even layer.
Pour the egg whites on top and tilt the skillet around to help them spread.
Cook the omelet until the egg whites begin to set.
Once they start to turn white, lift up the edges of the omelet with a spatula for a few seconds.
This will allow any uncooked egg white to flow underneath and cook.
Sprinkle the cheese down the middle of the omelet.
Start with the cottage cheese, then finish off with a sprinkle of parmesan.
If you don't have these two cheeses on hand, you can try ricotta and/or Romano instead.
You can also omit one of the cheeses and just use one type.
Mozzarella is another tasty option.
Fold the omelet in half.
Slide a spatula under the omelet partway, then quickly flip it over like closing a book.
Alternatively, you can fold both of the side edges to the middle so that they overlap, like a brochure.
Slide the omelet onto a plate and serve it.
Do this quickly; the egg whites will continue to cook even after you remove them from the skillet.
If you want to, you can garnish the omelet further with some diced tomatoes or sun dried tomatoes.
Making Hearty Muffin Cups Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C).
Grease a 12-count muffin tin with butter, oil, or cooking spray, then set it aside.
For smaller cups, use a 24-count mini muffin tin.
Pour 2½ cups (595 milliliters) of egg whites into a bowl.
You use store-bought egg whites that come in a carton, or you can separate the egg whites yourself using fresh eggs.
If you plan on using fresh eggs, however, you will need 20 to 24 eggs.
For a fluffier muffin, add 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of non-fat milk or plain, Greek yogurt.
Stir the vegetables and herbs into the bowl.
You can also use other vegetables or create your own unique combination.
Other great choices include: bacon crumbles, ham, onions, red peppers, and sausage.
If you are making these for your family, consider putting the ingredients into bowls, then letting your family members build their own muffin cups.
Whisk in the cheese, salt, and pepper.
You can also try other cheeses, such as colby or pepper jack.
Feta cheese goes especially well with mushrooms and spinach.
Pour the mixture into the muffin cups.
Fill each cup about two-thirds of the way; this will give the muffin cups space to rise.
Make things easier by using a soup or sauce ladle for this step; this way you can be sure that each cup gets the same amount.
Bake the muffin cups for 20 to 25 minutes.
They are ready when the egg whites turn white and puffy.
If you are making mini muffins, reduce the baking time to 15 to 20 minutes.
Allow the muffin cups to cool before removing them from the pan.
Place the muffin pan on a wire cooling rack, and let the muffin cups cool for about 5 minutes.
Run a knife along the inside edge of each cup, then scoop the muffin cup out with a fork.
Garnish the muffin cups, if desired, then serve them.
You can serve them with diced avocado, salsa, or a sprinkle of fresh herbs, such as chives.
Allow any leftover muffin cups to cool completely before freezing them; store them in plastic, re-sealable freezer bags.
Re-heat frozen muffin cups in the microwave for 45 seconds.
Making a Baked Mushroom Omelet Preheat the broiler on your oven.
Move the rack until it is 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) from the heat.
While the oven pre-heats, you will prepare the omelet on the stovetop.
Sauté the shallot and thyme in a skillet.
Heat 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of melted butter in a medium-sized, nonstick skillet over medium heat.
Add in the shallot and thyme, and cook until they turn fragrant, stirring constantly.
This will only take about 30 seconds.
Make sure that you are using an oven-safe skillet, such as cast-iron on.
Use a potholder or oven mitt to handle the skillet.
Add in the mushrooms, salt, and pepper, and continue cooking.
Toss in the sliced mushrooms, then season them with some salt and pepper.
Allow the mushrooms to cook over medium-high heat until they brown slightly.
This will take about 5 minutes.
If you don't like mushrooms, you can try spinach instead, or even diced tomatoes!
Keep in mind that the cooking times may differ.
Whisk together the egg whites, salt, pepper, and butter.
While the mushrooms are cooking, separate the egg whites from the yolks, and place them into a bowl; reserve the yolks for another recipe.
Add in some salt and pepper, and 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of melted butter.
Whisk everything together until the whites turn frothy and doubled in volume.
This will give you a fluffier omelet in the end.
Add the egg whites and cook them over medium-low heat.
Use a spatula to lift the edges of the omelet up so that the uncooked egg white can flow underneath it.
You are ready for the next step when the egg whites begin to set and turn light brown on the bottom; this will take about 3 minutes.
Place the skillet into the oven.
Let the omelet bake until the top sets, about 10 to 30 seconds.
As soon as the top sets, use a potholder or oven mitt to pull the skillet out of the oven.
Fold the omelet in half or into thirds.
Slide a spatula under half of the omelet, then flip it over onto itself.
Alternatively, you can fold the left and right sides to the middle so that they overlap.
Serve the omelet on a plate.
Use the spatula to slide the omelet off of the skillet and onto a plate.
